author: Koman

description.text:
The Prism printer has a belt-driven, single-stepper Z axis. A flaw in the original design of the printer was that when the belt was tight, there was no allowance for inconsistent pulleys. If you have non-circular, erratic pulleys, you would get z wobble as the z axis turned. the belt would squeeze everything it was connected to, and what would usually give was the Z bearing block that is attached to the aluminum extrusion, and so the Z leadscrew would pivot back and forth in the x direction.  
This piece allows some give but still allows proper tension on the belt. use this as an idler instead of a 624 attached directly to the extrusion.
A requested and delivered simple, artistic-ish phone stand.

author: Opar

title: XBee U.Fl With Large Antenna Protector

description.text:
Have you glued your antenna to a stick, glued the stick to a helmet, put on the helmet, then tried to walk through a doorway only to find you have destroyed a perfectly good XBee? Well fear no more! Print a protecting case! Here are links to the parts used in this project:
XBee with U.FL Connector
Interface Cable
Large Duck Antenna
XBee Explorer USB
  • (4) M3x12 Bolts
    • Enjoy!

I printed in ABS so if it decides to run into another door frame it can have a bit of flex. Simply bolt the two halves together with (4) M3x12 Bolts *Edit
Don't use the little nut from the interface cable. It's no longer needed anyway since the case is holding everything. By not using it you get a little slack in your interface cable thus giving you added projection in case of a traumatic smack down!
  • Thanks to Notloc in the comments for the suggestion.

comments.text: I like it. Those XBees are expensive little bugs. I might suggest you make the box a little shorter, so that the coax isn't straight. As is it, if you were to bend the antenna the sma connector would lever against the case and since the coax is already tight, it would put a lot of shear force on the U.LF connector on the XBee, maybe breaking it off. If there was slack in the coax, it would be less of an issue.
comments.author: notloc

comments.text: Ah that's a fantastic idea. And guess what? If I take the little nut off that's tightens up the UFL cable to the antenna there will be about 2mm of slack that I can move the antenna down thus giving a little slack to the cable. Thank you for the suggestion! Definitely do not want to break another one!

description.text: So I was getting to mounting my Pixhawk 2 to my new frame and noticed the cube is off-center on the carrier board. I created this model for you guys to print. It has the cube centered with the four inner holes, and has the drilling portions marked.

Some parts for Hypercube 3D printer that better suit my preferences. Captive nuts to ease assembly, changed direction from which screws are inserted. Flat bottom on X carriage so that LED strip may be installed.

BLTouch_mount_AL_1.5.stl raises BLTouch sensor by 1.5mm. This was necessary as my sensor's probe was lower than nozzle when retracted using the previous version.

New version of E3D mount released by Tech2C. My changes applied to it in E3D_mount_v1.1_AL.stl
X carriage doesn't really differ much, but I've applied my changes to it as well
X_Carriage_v1.2_AL.stl
BLTouch mount for the new E3D mount BLTouch_mount_1.1_AL.stl

Video about latest version 1.1 of E3D mount
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T9XAfLj8WXA
Video discussing my changes:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MYXsmhKzDCk
And another one in which I mention X carriage allowing mounting of LED strip.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f6wNO6v0NKo
Controller mount, LCD enclosure and mount, BLTouch mount
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QhrLO-29iV4

X carriage with integrated tensioner - you need to also print bumpers from the original tensioner part https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2092237
For the secont version of it, X_Carriage_v1.2_tensioner2_AL, I tried maintaining original low profile of X carriage. In order to keep things aligned I had to cut into X carriage which then left very little "meat" on it for nuts to grab. Use at your own risk. Print original tensioner and flip it around. Pinch belt against X carriage.

Hypercube:

comments.text: That's intentional. This should be just a single or two layer support. Without it, your printer would try to print circle encompassing bolt hole in thin air with nothing below it. With this support - a thin solid surface gets printed on which subsequent layers of hole get printed reliably. After printing you just drill out the hole. I usually do this when going from bigger diameter to a smaller one.

description.text:
Although it doesn't need it, I made a cover for the mainboard of my Anet A8. My cats seem very interested in all the flickering lights and repairing cats and or 3D printers is expensive.

I didn't want to have to add a fan, so the open hex grid should not obstruct airflow to the heat sinks.

To attach the cover, just remove the M3 nuts and screw the M3 screws into the holes in the legs. The hole is just small enough to give the thread something to bite into, without being too hard to screw into.

If you want something a little more secure, you could place the M3 nut over the hole, then press the nut into the plastic with a hot soldering iron, making sure you keep the nut level.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Nothing special needed. I just used the Cura defaults for my printer to print. It took about 2 and a half hours and used about 7m of PLA (20g).

I have been asked how I press the reset button. The wrong end plastic pen fits through for now, but if it becomes an issue, I might make a hexagonal button extension that fits through the nearest hole.
I took some measurements for size and screw placement and created a simple cover in 123D Design.

title: X and Y bushings for Hypercube

description.text:
I recommend using white or clear plastic so that you may inspect wear after use.

Source file has to be tailored to your specific printer. Read through source carefully to understand which settings to change.

Based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16813
Bushing to be used with US sized 3/8" (9.5mm) aluminum rod instead of 10mm rod which seems hard to find.

Video discussing these bushings:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f6wNO6v0NKo

XY joiner part fits original XY joiner designed for LM8UU bearings but works with 10mm rods.

Never mind the LM8UU mentioned in the file name. i just reused original file's name to remember on what this was based.

author: Shadowmaker72

title: Stereographic projection maze
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When I first saw the amazing Stereographic projection, one of the challenges I setup is doing the stereographic projection with a self-generating maze. From then on, a year has passed and it's finally completed.

The customizer will generate a different maze every time you run it. You may input different values for the maze_rows parameter. The sphere radius would be block_width * maze_rows / 6. What the block_width parameter means is each block's width in the maze shadow, so is wall_width. The line_steps parameter determines the smoothness of the sphere surface. A higher value would get a more smooth surface, however, more time for rendering a model.

If you want to print it, I recommend using a slicing software that you can add support structures manually because some overhangs can't be detected when generating automatic supports. Trying a maze with a smaller maze_rows would be a good start. Once it's printed successfully, you may challenge a bigger one. :)

Updated 2017/1/15: One day, I hit upon a great idea. If we waive the maze algorithm aside, there exists an easy way to perform a stereographic projection in OpenSCAD. I published a thing based on the idea some other day.

Find all my mazes in the collection "maze generators".

Find my things about stereographic projection in stereographic_projection.

  • OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

Printer:

CR8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

layer 0.2 mm

Infill:

100%

Do you want to know how to create mazes with OpenSCAD? The following documents may help.

  • Manual maze
  • Binary tree algorithm
  • Random maze

My library dotSCAD has a stereographic_extrude module. You can use it to create a thing of stereographic projection easily.

  • stereographic_extrude

print_settings.Notes:: All of these parts require supports during printing. The frames have square plug holes, be sure to clean out the support material completely. The ducts are oriented so there are no internal supports required, but leave the slicer support set to "Everywhere".
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: i3 v2.0 OR v2.1 Rear Mount Cooling Fan Frame for 60 mm OR 40 mm fan

description.text:
This is a snap on OR bolt on frame for the i3 v2.0 OR i3 v2.1 (MK10 hot end) to mount a 60 mm OR 40 mm fan, that goes on the back of the X axis carriage. It is modular for printing ease and simple changing of the fan / duct.

UPDATE
I have added a rear duct that holds a usb camera, see below for more info.

There are two versions of the v2.0 frame. One is a tight fit snap on. The other is simpler to mount, but requires two 3 mm x 8 mm bolts with nuts OR one thin zip tie about 100 mm long.

There is currently one version of the v2.1 frame. It requires two 3 mm x 18 mm bolts with nuts (washers are suggested) OR one thin zip tie about 120 mm long.

There are two versions of the duct part, which holds the fan. One is sized for a 60mm fan and the other is for a 40mm fan.

Any of the ducts will snap on to any of the frames. The fan duct simply plugs into the square holes on the back of the frame. You will likely have to trim the square plugs on the duct and also the square holes on the frame, as it is a tight fit.

When removing support from inside the duct be careful you don't remove the thin guide walls inside. They are very thin - 0.8 mm.

I printed at 2.0 mm layer with 40 % infill in PLA.

USB CAMERA MOUNT - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2208781
This is a 60 mm axial fan duct that holds a 6 mm usb camera - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00N4L5N4A/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

IN PROGRESS - I am making a blower fan duct, that will be half as long, so it won't stick out the back as far. Also, I am extending the nozzle out some, to be closer to the hot end.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

2.0 mm

Infill:

40 %

Notes:

All of these parts require supports during printing. The frames have square plug holes, be sure to clean out the support material completely. The ducts are oriented so there are no internal supports required, but leave the slicer support set to "Everywhere".

CAUTION

Be careful removing the support material from inside the ducts. The guide walls inside are only 0.8 mm thick, easy to confuse with the support walls.

These are designed for husky brand sockets, so they may not fit other brands correctly. I attached the solidworks files for the plates so you can adjust the sizes.

The brackets are not peg-compatible and use screws, but it would be a cool feature to add in the future.

The holes for each socket are tapered so pushing the sockets in gives a tight enough fit to hold them. The brackets are designed so that the plates can be removed when you are using them.

For the metric sockets, the numbers are in mm. for the imperial, they are in 64ths of an inch (trying to fit fractions in the space was not feasible with my printer).

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
New version of my previous "pic holder". It's a little clip that you can put on your guitar strap in order to put your pic there when you don't need it. Works fine with 0.8 to 1mm pics.  
Three sizes for the different sizes of strap (nylon, leather...)   
Print at 100% infill for the strenght and bend the stronger arm to set it on your strap. The little one should bend a little to snap your pic.  
Rock on !

title: P3Steel Lead Screw X-Axis Ends, Modified from Toolson's P3Steel -KaiTek

description.text:
This is a modified version of Toolson's P3Steel X-Axis ends, to use Lead Screws, as common on Sunhokey and other 3rd party prusa printers.

This is not a complete X-Axis, For a complete X Axis you will also need the following parts from "P3Steel Toolson Edition":
Belt tensioner,
X End stop bracket,
Y End stop trigger (either short or long)
Y End stop bracket

Printer Brand:

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

40%

Notes:

You will need a few tools for this.
2.5mm, 8mm,10mm drill bits or reamer
M3 Tap

After printing clean up edges, then drill or ream holes to spec.

For the Leadscrew nut, you must drill/ream the 4 small screw holes to 2.5mm, then tap with M3 thread,.

The middle hole you must drill/ream to 10mm, and the X rod holes to 8mm.

The Leadscrew nut should press in firmly, and the M3 Screws hold it securely in place.

comments.author: MrGlass

description.text:
This is an updated version of my extruder. This version uses a 3mm screw to mount the bearing to the lever arm. It's much stronger and will last forever.

After experiencing a very, very high failure rate when printing Ninjaflex, I decided to go look for a solution. That's when I came across the extruder made by Singh336. It was good extruder indeed and I was able to successfully print both Ninjaflex and TPU. But, when I tried a TPE 80A filament, it jammed in the extruder the same way NInjaflex does with the stock EZStruder. TPE 80A is softer and more flexable than Ninjaflex

I felt there were also a few deficiencies in Singh336's extruder so I decided to create my own. While mine is created from scratch, it is heavily based on the design by Singh336.

Benefits:

  1. The lever arm won't twist like the stock lever arm.
  2. The Knob has a flattened spot to perfectly fit the stepper shaft.
  3. It has a mount.
  4. The feeder hole is closer and better aligned with the hob roller and bearing.
  5. The spring block is closer to the lever providing a more compressed spring and increased pressure on filament.
  6. The filament entry is taller and funnel shaped making it much easier to insert filament.
  7. All parts can be printed without supports.

Suggestions:
The lever arm must be strong and stiff. I recommend a high infill setting with honeycomb pattern..
The knob is a very tight fight and may require a little bit of filing to get it on.
Use an 8mm socket and screwdriver style handle to screw the pressure fitting into the hole.

Hardware:
3 - M3 x 8mm screws (mounting extruder to stepper motor)
1 - M3 X 25mm screw(mounting extruder through lever arm to stepper motor)
1 - M3 x 16mm screw (for mounting bearing onto lever arm)
5 - M3 washers
1 - M3 nut (for mounting bearing onto lever arm)
2 - #6 X 1.5 inch screws (for mounting. Or just reuse the original screws, but they are a bit long)
2 - #6 locknuts (can re-use original locknuts)
1 - 3x10x4 mm bearing (just re-use the original bearing from the lever arm)

Addtional note:
While I've had a 100% success rate with Ninjaflex and TPU filaments. printing with TPE 80A is still a challenge and I do get failures with that very soft filament. Then again, it's just tough to use filament that soft with a bowden tube setup anyways.

comments.text: Hey, Ive been following your youtube channel and I wanted to thank you for the videos.... Now that thats said, I have a buddy that I actually built a v2 for and he wants me to upgrade his etruder to print tpe and tpu. Can I suggest this design to him with 100% confidence it will do that for him?
comments.author: CABBYPAT

comments.text:
Hi. Thanks buddy!
I've printed tons of TPU and Ninaflex without any issue. 100% success with them.
I have TPE 80A which is quite soft and I still have a problems with it. That stuff is just really tough to print with a bowden tube.
This extruder is quite easy to make and doesn't take long to print. It's still an improvement over the stock extruder, even if it does still have some difficulty with TPE 80A.
Let me know how it works out!
Cheers.

title: Wanhao D6 / Monoprice ultimate improved fan duct

description.text:
This is a upgraded fan duct for the existing fan in a Wanhao duplicator 6 or Monoprice maker ultimate. It is designed to use the existing screws and fan for minimal change.

After looking around a bit I found http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1826526 which had everything I will be looking for when I eventually do a dual fan setup and included the original 123D file to be able to make modifications. I modified it to remove the second fan and connector pieces. I also noticed that the areas where the screws connect it to the fan were thicker than the original duct so I thinned those out to 2mm so that the original screws could still be used. I left in the back "wall" that wraps around the fan as I found it made it a little easier to attach the duct to the fan and made it feel a little more solid.

I printed this in PLA and it has worked great for me for PLA and woodfill printing with the tip getting up to 210 for the woodfill, however if you are printing in ABS or other materials that require higher heat I would recommend printing this out of a different material as it could potentially melt during printing (The original post recommended PETG). I have not tested the heat limits of this duct beyond 210.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Ultimate

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I had supports for anywhere above the print bed, this left the inside of the duct near the tip a bit rough, but it ensured the screw holes printed correctly.

comments.text: I have printed and used this duct with excellent results. I've even used it while printing ABS while being enclosed with no issues.

author: costonb

description.text:
Photoscaning of a teddy bear and processing in AutoDesk ReMake.

This is a 3D scan project I did with AutoDesk ReMake software. I took 72 pictures around a teddy bear using my phone, uploaded pictures to ReMake. ReMake generated a preliminary 3D model of the bear (which was already pretty good), and I use ReMake, Meshlab and Meshmixer to further flx, clean, modify the model.

There are two models (in obj format). puppy3-1.obj is the high resolution one and puppy_reduced.obj is the lower resolution one. The .mtl file (material) has to be located in the same folder with the .obj file. To get texture, download the puppy3-101.zip file and unzip it to get puppy3-101.jpg texture file. Put the .jpg in the same folder with .obj and .mtl. Simply open the .obj file in meshlab and the texture should be automatically loaded.

description.text:
This is part of a laser tag LARP style system I worked on. The entire system is open source so if you want to contribute check out..

https://github.com/moonbeaminteractive

The bow uses a rotary encoder in the arm axis to trigger a fire event with an arduino pro mini, an infrared led and a laser for targeting.

The infrared tube has a internal ring set at 45mm which allows the IR LED to be pushed into place without having to worry about focus. I also printed the LED holder with a small aperture in order to keep the spread down. the Normal width of the LED gets magnified to about 6 feet over 20 meters without the aperture.

Here is a video of the bow firing.

You'll need..

1 google cardboard lens 45mm focal length
1 arduino pro mini or similar small controller board
1 IR LED
1 laser pointer module (optional)
some small guage weed eater cord for the bow string
some #2 1/2" and 3/8" wood screws for securing parts if they are loose
2 104 ceramic capacitors for hardware debouncing the rotary encoder (very much needed)
1 50R - 150R resistor (depending on fire time for LED. Lower means brighter and a longer projection for the IR signal but could burn out the LED if left on to long)

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Resolution:

0.35mm

Infill:

varies by part

Notes:

Bigger parts can use infill. The bow handle can be 35 to 50 percent infill. The Arms I printed at 50-75 percent infill and the rest of the parts I printed solid with no shells for fit. Every thing should snap together with a little sanding on the edges for heat bed flattening.

Code for Arduino Pro Mini sketch

/Interrupt-based Rotary Encoder Sketch
by Simon Merrett, based on insight from Oleg Mazurov, Nick Gammon, rt, Steve Spence
*/

static int pinA = 3; // Our first hardware interrupt pin is digital pin 2
static int pinB = 2; // Our second hardware interrupt pin is digital pin 3
volatile byte aFlag = 0; // let's us know when we're expecting a rising edge on pinA to signal that the encoder has arrived at a detent
volatile byte bFlag = 0; // let's us know when we're expecting a rising edge on pinB to signal that the encoder has arrived at a detent (opposite direction to when aFlag is set)
volatile byte encoderPos = 0; //this variable stores our current value of encoder position. Change to int or uin16_t instead of byte if you want to record a larger range than 0-255
volatile byte oldEncPos = 0; //stores the last encoder position value so we can compare to the current reading and see if it has changed (so we know when to print to the serial monitor)
volatile byte reading = 0; //somewhere to store the direct values we read from our interrupt pins before checking to see if we have moved a whole detent

static int infraLED = 9;
static int laserSite = 10;
boolean arrowKnocked = false;

void setup() {
pinMode(pinA, INPUT_PULLUP); // set pinA as an input, pulled HIGH to the logic voltage (5V or 3.3V for most cases)
pinMode(pinB, INPUT_PULLUP); // set pinB as an input, pulled HIGH to the logic voltage (5V or 3.3V for most cases)
pinMode(infraLED, OUTPUT);
pinMode(laserSite, OUTPUT);
attachInterrupt(0,PinA,RISING); // set an interrupt on PinA, looking for a rising edge signal and executing the "PinA" Interrupt Service Routine (below)
attachInterrupt(1,PinB,RISING); // set an interrupt on PinB, looking for a rising edge signal and executing the "PinB" Interrupt Service Routine (below)
Serial.begin(115200); // start the serial monitor link
}

void PinA(){
cli(); //stop interrupts happening before we read pin values
reading = PIND & 0xC; // read all eight pin values then strip away all but pinA and pinB's values
if(reading == B00001100 && aFlag) { //check that we have both pins at detent (HIGH) and that we are expecting detent on this pin's rising edge
encoderPos --; //decrement the encoder's position count
bFlag = 0; //reset flags for the next turn
aFlag = 0; //reset flags for the next turn
}
else if (reading == B00000100) bFlag = 1; //signal that we're expecting pinB to signal the transition to detent from free rotation
encoderPos = 0;
Serial.println("Pin A interrupt");
sei(); //restart interrupts
}

void PinB(){
cli(); //stop interrupts happening before we read pin values
reading = PIND & 0xC; //read all eight pin values then strip away all but pinA and pinB's values
if (reading == B00001100 && bFlag) { //check that we have both pins at detent (HIGH) and that we are expecting detent on this pin's rising edge
if(encoderPos < 1){
encoderPos ++; //increment the encoder's position count
}else{
encoderPos = 1;
}
bFlag = 0; //reset flags for the next turn
aFlag = 0; //reset flags for the next turn
}
else if (reading == B00001000) aFlag = 1; //signal that we're expecting pinA to signal the transition to detent from free rotation
Serial.println("Pin B interrupt");
sei(); //restart interrupts
}

void loop(){
if(encoderPos > 1){
encoderPos = 1;
}

if(encoderPos > 0){
arrowKnocked = true;
}

if(arrowKnocked == true && encoderPos < 1){
arrowKnocked = false;
digitalWrite(infraLED, HIGH);
delay(100);
digitalWrite(infraLED, LOW);
digitalWrite(laserSite, LOW);
}else if(arrowKnocked == true && encoderPos > 0){
digitalWrite(laserSite, HIGH);
delay(100);
digitalWrite(laserSite, LOW);
}

if(oldEncPos != encoderPos) {
Serial.println(encoderPos);
if(encoderPos > 1){
encoderPos = 1;
}
oldEncPos = encoderPos;
}
//delay(200);
}

description.text:
Salut à tous !

Voilà mon premier objet modélisé et imprimé en 3D pour notre groupe 5beOz.
Dès notre arrivée dans notre appartement à Melbourne, on s'est rendu compte qu'il n'y avait pas de cendrier, on utilisait donc des canettes de soda.
Du coup j'ai décidé de réutiliser le design des canettes de 33cl de coca pour modéliser un cendrier.

Apres avoir utilisé le cendrier pendant 2 mois il est arrivé que certaines cigarettes soient mal éteinte et fassent des trous dans l'objet. Je recommande donc de placer une feuille d'aluminium à l'intérieur du cendrier et sur le capuchon. Ils vous suffit de faire des trous dans le papier d'alu au niveau du capuchon.

Enjoy et n'hésitez pas à retrouver nos aventures sur les réseaux sociaux : https://www.facebook.com/5beoz

title: Eric's Improved Z Axis Coupler Rev3

description.text: **5/19/2015 Updated EricCouplerRev3-5x5mm.stl for 5mm motor & 5mm threaded rod, M5 nut dimensions estimated. This should work for i3 machines and any other fine 5mm rods. let me know if the nut needs to be modified. 11/4/2013 v4.2, 6mm: Beveled the unsupported edge for the 6mm nut, Beveled the m3 Nylock grub screw hole and narrowed it .2mm, for a tighter fit. Please let me know if you need any other mods. 9/1/2013 modded v4 ->4.1: 6mm version for better 6mm nut fit and widened grub for a nylock nut. removed opposing grub and widened body to 22mm 8/26/13 Added 6mm and 8mm versions Bridged with a second opposite grub on the 5mm motor shaft. Coupler for Z Axis, Revision 3: Beefed up a little. Created in PTC Creo

8/26/13 Added 6mm and 8mm versions, Bridged with a second opposite grub on the 5mm motor shaft.
This is the 3rd rendition of my Coupler, a few adjustments were made to make it more robust. 1.) I moved the nuttrap for the 5mm shaft down and back to increase strength, since mine were vibrating loose over time. 2.) I adjusted the supports in the large nut trap. I may close the top layer and try to print this with direct bridging instead of the supports. it might print more cleanly, but I'll save that for next time. 3.) I widened the bottom opening to make shaft insertion easier. the upper is still the same diameter for threading the rod into. Instructions:
  • Print 2x of these couplers.
  • Insert a nut into the top, nut trap and push it down to line up with an M3 screw. Tighten onto your 5mm stepper shaft.
  • Cut out the supports for the large trap, Insert a nut into the large trap.
  • Thread a nut and a washer onto your threaded Z rod, then screw your rod up through the large trapped nut and into the coupler until it stops.
  • Tighten the nut on the rod up against the washer and the bottom of the Coupler.
    • Your coupler should now be centered on the stepper motor shaft. Please let me know if you need any changes. 4MM, added nuts etc.
    I created these in PTC Creo Elements. it's free, and easy to use. Both .STL and .PK2 files are included.

-------------------------------Español-------------------------------
Chasis para un vehículo de pruebas, para cortar en laser, fabricado en acrílico de 3mm (fotos) pero se podría cortar en cualquier otro material y cualquier otro espesor.

Se agregan soportes para servos, y para los ejes traseros que manejan las orugas, además de las ruedas para imprimir en 3D, para la oruga utilice una correa 103XL de 20mm de ancho.

La electrónica que se ve en las imágenes es un BeagleboneBlack, un regulador de voltaje switching (buck-boost) de 3A y dos servos estándar

La altura de los pisos son separadores de diferentes tamaños que dependerán del uso que se le dé a cada piso, la recomendación es separar las etapas de la electrónica, También se podría utilizar un tornillo largo y afirmar los pisos con tuercas

-------------------------------English-------------------------------
Chassis for a test vehicle, laser cutting, made of 3mm acrylic (photos) but could be cut into any other material and any other thickness.

Servo holders are added, and for the rear axles that drive the caterpillars, in addition to the wheels for 3D printing, for the caterpillar use a 103XL 20mm wide belt.

The electronics seen in the images are a BeagleboneBlack, a switching regulator (buck-boost) of 3A and two standard servos

The height of the floors are separators of different sizes that will depend on the use given to each floor, the recommendation is to separate the stages of the electronics, You could also use a long screw and assert the floors with nuts

remixed_from.author: abuharsky
remixed_from.title: iPhone 5 car mount for steering wheel Prius

title: Prius iPhone 7 Plus behind Steering Wheel mount

description.text:
Mount to hold iPhone 7Plus behind the steering wheel of a Toyota Prius (I have a 2012). OpenSCAD source files provided so you an make it fit your phone.

I used the base.stl from bhoffman's mount but discovered that when I printed his left and right pieces, they wouldn't fit at all onto the base, and since my phone was not in a case if they had fit my phone would have fallen right out.

After I posted all of this, I found the similar but I only discovered it after I had made this page.

So, I re-did his base in OpenSCAD:

base.scad - a version of the missing model of base.stl. I didn't actually test print this file, I just printed bhoffman's original base.stl. (scaled 91% in just the Z axis so it would fit my small printer.)

tee.scad - a model of the 'T' joint of the base, so I could subtract away from the left and right pieces. Just included by the other files.

mate.scad - quick print test - you can adjust the dimensions of the print so it fits snuggly on your base.

right.scad - The right half case. You can adjust the dimensions to fit your phone.
rightPlus.scad - The right half case with a hole for the lightning cable.

left.scad - The left half case. I include right.scad and just mirror reflect it.
leftPlus.scad - The left half case with a cutout for the 7 Plus camera bulge.

I did over - you can use leftPlus and rightPlus for what I'm using now, but I left right and left as the originals so you can diff the .scad files and see how easy it is to modify

I'm happy with the result: the base fits snuggly into the channel behind the steering wheel, and the left and right sides fit snuggly into the 'tee' channel at the front of the base, and the phone fits just right into the left and right pieces.

Now I'm writing an iOS app to give me easy access to the data and controls I've been missing - sort of a personal CarPlay.

This is all OpenSCAD, so feel free to play with it. just comment out the module call at the end of the file and write a different module call instead. use '%' to make solids translucent or '#' to make visible and translucent solids that were differenced away.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Shell thickness 1.6

PLA at 190°C, bed heater off.

Print the base, print the mate, and verify that it fits pretty tightly on the base. Then remove it.
then print one of the two lefts, and one of the two rights.

3/4/17 followup: PLA isn't good for something you leave in the car.

I printed this in PLA in the winter and it was great. But, as soon as I left the car out in the sun on a warm day, the PLA started sagging. So: I'm happy with design, but not PLA as the material.

title: Miniature Painting Holding Stick
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Miniature Painting Sticks.

No more paint bottles corks and other weird contraptions.

I have made these to be an all in one solution for painting 28mm scale models. More specifically Warhammer 40K by GW.

There is a number of different mounting options available for the models. Plastic base insert types can be pushed in the slot. Other models that use a 3mm pin can also be pushed straight into the stand. The standard base size fits perfectly on top and can be held on with blu-tack or tape. Models pinned to paperclips etc can be easily taped to the side.

An 8mm Hole is also included in the base of the stick. This can be put on an 8mm bolt or rod for stability while spraying. Or for mounting on a stand. Or any other use you can think of.

comments.text: What are you using as a source? Looks like that tube is sensitive to gamma, so a Cesium/Cobalt sample disc of some type?

This tube is also sensitive to beta. I am using a little piece of vintage fiestaware china plate
( http://www.nuclearconnect.org/in-the-classroom/for-teachers/classroom-resources/radiation-sources-for-teachers
https://farm4.static.flickr.com/3775/9676341046_3ef5506ed0_b.jpg )

description.text: This is a replacement for the step hinges on an older model of the simplehuman 38L rectangular step trash can. There is a model of the original hinge, and one that is designed to use an m3 captive nut and bolt that is a little more substantive. Using the latter will require expanding the channels the hinges rest in slightly (a razor knife works fine for this). The former is untested and honestly it's so flimsy (per the original dimensions) I would expect it to break unless printed in metal. :)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

I recommend printing this as 3 parts in the x-y plane to increase strength and avoid thin overhangs.
Superglue the 3 parts together.

author: melone89

description.text:
Dieser Quadcopter wurde für das FPV Flugtraining entwickelt. Racing Kopter sind teuer, sehr schnell und agil. Das erste fliegen mit dem Racing Kopter und Brille kann in folge schnell teuer werden.

Dieser Kopter ist auf Stabilität und geringe Kosten optimiert. Ersatzteile sind schnell produziert und Komponenten günstig zu bekommen.

Folgende Komponenten passen perfekt:
1 x Naze32 Acro
4 x Turnigy 2215J Motor
4 x 30A ESC
2 x 10;45 CW Prop
2 x 10;45 CCW Prop
LIPO ca. 2200mAh
TX und RX

Für den FPV Flug:
1 x QUANUM 700TVL SONY 1/3 CCD-Kamera 2.8mm Objektiv (PAL)
1 x Quanum ELITE QE58-6 5,8GHz AV Sender
Nach belieben einen AV Empfänger und Videobrille

Die Baseplate wird am besten gefräst, kann aber auch gedruckt werden. Für die Ausleger wird jeweils ein Rahmenteil und ein Motorteil benötigt. Die Ausleger selbst sind aus 8mm Alurohr mit einer länge von 182mm. Die gedruckten Bohrungen müssen mit einer Bohrmaschine, nach dem montieren der Rohre, mit einem 3mm Bohrer durchgebohrt werden.
LA LINEA HAPPY NEW YEAR 2017

author: ronaldor

description.text:
I remixed this primarily to allow the sealing lid for a ball jar to fit easily under the dispenser
valve so the jar can be tightly sealed (popcorn needs to be kept at the proper moisture for
optimal popping). I also changed the "split line" to allow the threaded portion of the valve
housing to be undivided. The ball is designed as one piece with built in supports. The
handle is fashioned after a water valve handle and is held on with a stainless steel washer
and 1/4-20 x 1/2" long Phillips head Cap Screw

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.01

Infill:

15%

Notes:

12-14-2017 Updated the housing file to add some small connection points between the two parts because with some materials one half would fall away while printing.
No Raft is necessary for the handle
I printed the housing and the handle in ABS and used 103% scale to allow for shrinkage
I printed the ball in ABS and used 102% scale and sanded outside lightly until it rotates smoothly
(103% seemed a bit to big)

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Nve7BJMaPiU" ></iframe>
It works great!

Items needed to complete
1.) 1 Phillips head cap screw Stainless Steel 1/4-20 UNC X 1/2" long
2.) 1 Washer Flat Stainless Steel #10
3.) 2 Phillips head cap screw Stainless Steel #8-32 UNF x 1/2" long
4.) 2 Nut, Acorn Brass #8-32 UNF

Simple brackets for holding an iPhone in landscape position or Dashboard mount.  Left and Right version are mirror image to asure alignement. I use it in the lab to hold the iphone on instruments while monitoring data feeds. Place adhesive tape under feet, hold feet on end of phone then press phone down on feet to stick brackets in desired location.  
Big opening leaves room for charger cable on one side while little notch leaves clearance for power switch.  
Meant to mount in Landscape position. This version is for NO case but you can scale it on one axis to fit with a case.

Download, scale to fit thickness of phone with or without case.
Print out left and right mirrored, then stick them in place with adhesive tape or maybe velcro pads. Enjoy

description.text:
My headset broke, so I fixed it. Needed some manipulation to get it on (a bit tight), but it worked out well. I can't tell the difference.

This is for the left earpiece, btw. the right one is not exactly mirrored, but feel free to try it, it might work.

Edit: FredF2015 informs he that it also fits the right side :)

Scanned the original and imported image to fusion 360. Calibrated canvas with measurements from the part. Then I could draw on top of it.

In hindsight I should have done more measurements to make it more precise, but it worked and saved me 1000NOK for a new headset.

comments.text: Great work!

description.text:
A fan guard for 40mm fan to keep fingers out:-)
Of course, it will fit any 40mm fan as long as there is a gap between the fan and this guard. ie, where the fan is mounted on one side of the enclosure and this guard on the other.

Not technically a remix I guess, but it was designed with the "My Fav Pi" case in mind.

author: xmas02300

print_settings.Notes:: Adding two versions - with a round handle and square handle for the probe

description.text:
Mine probe is: LJ12A3-4-Z/BX - 22mm mounting probe with 4mm distance detection. First prints worked fine. Still some fine tuning needed.

If you are using standard given firmware you need to change following lines:
282 - check your polarisation of your probe: NPN - true; PNP - false;
const bool Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = true;
335 - uncomment
define ENABLE_AUTO_BED_LEVELING
384 - offset only on x axis: 38.78
define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 38.78
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

Known problems in firmware:
Marlin_main.cpp
line 995 - just add brackets to values
do_blocking_move_to((x - X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER), (y - Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER), current_position[Z_AXIS]);

Printer:

FLsun3d

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

85

Notes:

Adding two versions - with a round handle and square handle for the probe
for post print you need to drill out holes for screws using 3mm metal drill bit (at least I needed to do it)

comments.text: What pins do i connect the probe to?

description.text:
Inspired by another bird model I enjoyed printing, assembling and painting (http://www.thingiverse.com/make:136861), I made similar modifications to this model to make it easier to print and assemble.

Use glue to assemble and fill the gaps between the body and head with Polyfilla or similar. Sand smooth and paint with acrylics. I printed the example shown here with 0% infill, 3 shells. No support is required.

Note: Two versions of the head are provided. If you prefer to print the head, beak and eyes in different colors, use Toucan_beak+support.stl, Toucan_eyes.stl and Toucan_head+peghole.stl. Otherwise, use Toucan_top-halves.stl.

Thanks to William_Additive!

description.text:
I needed to attach a different sized hose to my Ozito wet dry vacuum, and I couldn't use the original ozito attachment.

So I designed this tapered cone/cylinder with a nub so I could attach it (this is so I can use the vacuum with a dust deputy with my mpcnc).

Hope this helps some one else.

As I had 3 shells for out side, this effectlively printed solid (6 shells 3mm thick).
Crochet rideau Peugeot 807 et intérieur garniture support porte avant droite

Having failed a few times at catching my printer before it runs out of filament, I finally decided to do something about it. I found the "Filament Sensor"-plugin for octoprint, and decided to use a microswitch to do the detection for me.

This is the result; It is attached right before my extruder, so I can use almost every last scrap of filament I have laying around.

Edit: Previous problems with rpi not booting was due to me brainfarting and connecting 3v3 and gnd with the 1k resistor between them. Somehow it still worked, but rpi did not boot. After wiring as described, it works as intended

Stuff I had laying about

So I have a lot of electronics crap laying around, so I figured I could use some of it for this. Among the crap, I have:

  • Many meters of thin cable-strips
  • Microswitches
  • Resistors of varying values
  • Dupont connectors
3D Design

What I did here was basicly to model a very rough model of the microswitches I planned on using, Then I made the holder around it.

The lever on the switch needed a little kink to make it pick up a better signal, which is completely OK by me.

Circuits.io didn't have a Rpi model, so strech your imagination here Circuit

To connect a button to the rpi3, I had to make a small circuit to avoid screwing it up.

Basicly you need a current-limiting resistor (R1) on your input-pin, so you don't ruin your rpi.
Then you need a pull-down (R2) to make the pin LOW by default.
Then you need to connect one lead from the switch between the resistors, and the other on a 3.3v supply. IMPORTANT: Don't use 5v, as apparently the rpi doesn't like that!

I used a Pin-out I found on google to figure out what pins were GND av 3.3v on the rpi, and chose GPIO 21 for the input signal.

If you can't figure out how this should map over to your rpi, you might not want to do this...

R1: 1k
R2: 10k

comments.text:
got a resistor between switch and ground?
Perhaps the lack of one is creating too much resistance (a short) for the Pi to startup.
comments.author: Eddiie

comments.text: I had wired the 1k resistor between gnd and 3v3, via the switch to the input pin. It's a wonder my rpi didn't brick... :P
comments.author: Eddiie

comments.text: Yeah, I thought the 1k currentlimiting resistor would be enough, but seems it isnt. Using a higher value here would probably serve the same purpose as adding another one inline with the switch, right?
comments.author: Eddiie

description.text:
Awesome design by http://www.thingiverse.com/PeterProvost

Remixed the frame to suit an Eachine-E010.
Moved the rear mount forward and created a space in the chassis for the battery connector.
The stock Eachine-E010 fc now fits the front and rear screw mounts.
Raised the side mounts so camera mounts now clear the stock Eachine fc.

05-06-2017 update
Well i mounted a eachine camera to this and was dissapointed that it barely made it off the ground. I tried an original frame and that was not much better. Im guessing ill either need bigger motors or bigger batteries........

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

0%

comments.text: Glue in the motors? the original has seats they friction fit into, maybe that could be added in the future. Going to print this out as my girl likes to see how fast she can smash into the ground and get me to glue it back together lol.
comments.author: FaceStuffer

comments.text: i didn't use any glue as the motors were a tight fit, the original designer suggested to use a bit of hot glue gun action for the motors though.
comments.author: FaceStuffer

comments.text: I found that the hot glue then heat shrink tip was the difference between the frame not taking to the air, and a great flyer. I assume the motors/props were coming out of the mounts just enough to reduce thrust. Tape does not work nearly as well as heat shrink, if you can get the heat shrink tight enough. Warning: don't melt the props when you do this - or have spares on hand!
comments.author: PaulsBoutique

comments.text: nice designed, but the quality of the mash is so bad that i actually get print issues as it gets sliced with holes
comments.author: simplesimson

comments.text: Really ?- that's interesting, mine printed fine - I can't take credit for the original design, I just modded the mount to fit the eachine in tinkercad. Have done a couple on different printers. I'm using the inbuilt cura from repetier, what slicer did you use ?
comments.author: simplesimson

comments.text: If you compare both the original and your modified mesh, it seems that the modded mesh is a lot less smooth and more irregular around the curved top of the fan ducts, tinkercad is probably doing something funny with it. From the description I understand that the only edits you made were moving the rear post and heightening the camera posts, and removing the piece of the frame next to the rear post to allow for the battery connector, so that shouldn't have affected the fan ducts. I'll probably make my own edit of the original to see if I can avoid the artifacts, also removing the camera posts because I don't plan on flying FPV any time soon. I'll give you credit for inspiration or something of course :P
comments.author: PaulsBoutique

comments.text:
Fair call, when i have a spare moment ill look at redoing the model completely too,as i have a few other ideas. Im sure your right on the tinkercad issues though.
I originally needed something asap as my kids go through frames quicker than underwear changes, and the original model was the only one around, hence the quick hacks.
comments.author: dj__jg

comments.text: FWIW, it sliced fine in MakerBot Desktop (so I think they call that slicer Miracle Grue?)  Haven't tried printing one since I got my gently-hacked Replicator 2X set up with Cura.

description.text: Since I wanted to stick a DUPLO brick to the feet of other objects, I modified the scad file with an extra 4th parameter (nibbles on or off) First try was: I imported models to Meshlab and killed the caps of the brick. A dumb way to it as the commenters pointed out :) This thing gave me the idea for a larger project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2106

More of the story is here:
http://edutechwiki.unige.ch/en/Meshlab_for_RapMan_tutorial and
http://edutechwiki.unige.ch/en/Sketchup_3D_printable_objects_tutorial

author: GRay_111111

description.text: This thing is a Camcover for the Macbook Pro Retina (mid2012).
This is a 100mm square (width & Length) and 10mm High hollow square with 1mm thick walls used to calibrate 3D printers for size.

How to calculate percentage of error?

Simply print this item out, and then measure the width and length to see if you 3D printer is creating a 100mm square. if it is not then you can calculate the error amount, and get your printing program to correct by that amount. (ie if you length and width print at 103mm then 100 divided 103 roughly equals 97. Then tell you 3D printing program to scale length and width by 97%)

author: jjasonmullins

description.text: A dual extruder version of the Half Dome 3d topo which prints the path of the trail on the second extruder. Also note the lettering on the side (why not since you've got the other extruder hotted up anyway) Note the detail photo showing the infamous cableway section. Complete instructions on how to make models from digital elevation data can be found on my blog at http://www.the3dprintedfuture.com/shapespeare/?p=1

DEM data comes from The National Map 1/3 arc sec data set.
Trail location comes from 7.5' topo.
Modeled in Blender
Sample printed on FlashForgeCreator with ABS. 7hrs 39min build time.

comments.text: I like apples new operating system. I think its great that you have decided to convert it to a 3d printable model!
comments.author: stustu242

comments.text:
demto3d--http://jawensi.wordpress.com/instalacion/demto3d--http://jawensi.wordpr...
Free software to make topographic models from GIS data
comments.author: jawensi

comments.text: The topo model is made using the instructions described at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27194/#instructionshttp://www.thingiverse.com/thi.... Then I took the STL into Blender and used "import image as plane" to import a picture of the topo map showing the trail. After aligning them I created a curve following the trail, solidified it and extruded it. Then I used a boolean intersect to trim the extrusion to match the curves of the topo and finally a boolean difference to punch out the hole for the second color. The text on the side is done in blender using extruded type and booleans to cut it in.

remixed_from.author: zennmaster
remixed_from.title: Z-probe holder for Makerfarm i3 with auto bed-level

description.text:
I found it critically important to have a sturdy and balanced design for a z probe holder, the original was quite flexible. This design aligns the microswitch contact point exactly below the servo rotation pivot for max stability. The design is parametric so you can modify the length of the probe from servo to microswitch. Make it as short as possible. I do use it on makerfarm, but I printed new x carriage assy so stock will probably need to be longer.  
I haven't found much use for auto-bed levelling as I prefer a level build platform, but I did find it useful for scanning the surface of the bed (which revealed that my X rods were bent) and its great help for measuring and manually levelling each corner.  
I did have to make changes to the marlin V1 firmware branch to support this fully. If someone needs it I can post a fork.

Printed in ABS with 50% infill. Clearances have been left for shrinkage. Clean it up manually to make sure all the parts snap in well and fully. Drill your own servo mount holes. Remove microswitch arm (too much bending) and make sure the switch and firmware are configured for normally open operation (push to close). The microswitch is much more repeatable this way. Attach switch using two screws, you can drill the microswitch holes out very slightly (<0.5mm) and selftap a thread in if you have to rather than overdrill. Use a cross horn for stability, trim the 3 protruding ends. Superglue the horn for best stability.

author: mawihtec

print_settings.Notes:: Unlike thingirob brackets, I have allowed tollerance in these parts where required, so should be able to print at 100% scaling.

title: Tevo Tarantula Single Motor Dual Z Axis

description.text:
These parts are designed to give the Tevo Tarantula Dual Z axis from a single motor. I won't go into the pros and cons here, as it's complicated. No more motor couplers though, so makes things easier! It is a little more fiddly than dual motors, although requires no extra electronics.

They are remixed from the excellent brackets by thingirob. I have remodeled these parts completely so they do look slightly different.Please note I have added tolerances where the original parts had none, these should print fine without scaling.

You need 2 of the Z Nut holders. I have included x2 in the name, but just to remind you.

Please note the photo I have included is v1. I have updated the designs since then to improve them based on my experiences.

Additional Hardware

You will need the following parts to put it together. Many of the screws etc. were spares from the kit, or left over from other changes I have made for the printer.

  • 900mm closed loop GT2 belt. I found a seller on AliExpress that made these very cheaply. Link may disappear if they stop selling them.
  • 4 x 608 Bearings
  • 2 x 400mm lead screws. Threads need to match. Also need standard brass nuts.
  • 2 x 8mm bore 20 tooth pulley. Seller I used
  • 5mm bore 20 tooth pulley for motor. Seller I used
  • 2 x Smooth Idler Pulleys w/ 16mm diameter. I had these so no seller, although commonly available. Basically same pulley used on other axes of Tarantula.
  • 2 x 25mm M5 Screws. Can be longer.
  • 2 x Nylon spaces or nuts.
  • M5 washers (to use to space idlers correctly. I used 4).
  • 2 x M5 nuts, ideally nylock nuts.
  • Nema 17 motor from original Z axis.
  • 4 x M3 screws to mount Motor (should already have these with original brackets).
  • 8 x M3 screws and nuts to mount brass nuts.
  • M4 T Nuts and screws. I won't include the amounts, however I would suggest using a minimum of 8 on each bracket, and 2 for each of the Nut holders. This would be 44 of each.
  • Optional 2 x 8mm lock collars. The screws are held in place by gravity, however you can add lock collars underneath the upper bearing bracket. I do not use them, as in the event that the print head crashes into bed, the screws lift out of the bearings and prevent damage.

Putting it together

Brackets and Lead Screws

  1. Put together the printer with the brackets as normal. Take care to try to align the brackets as best as possible.
  2. Insert bearings into relevant spaces in brackets. Should fit well, although may need some sanding depending on how well your printer is set up.
  3. Add brass nut to Z nut holders. Use M3 screws and nuts to securely fasten.
  4. Attach 8mm bore pulleys to end of lead screws and tighten grub screws well.
  5. Insert Lead screws through upper bearings, then thread on Z nuts, finally push lead screws into bottom bearings. If using 400mm screws, none of the screw will come out the other side, this bearing just supports it at each end.
  6. Secure z nut holders to X axis. Care should be taken here to measure the distance from each side to a fixed point on the frame (top or bottom, not the bed), to ensure it is square. Use the lead screws to adjust up and down manually. It is easiest to have the T nuts in the slots properly, but leave them loose while adjusting, and tighten only at the end.

Motor Mount

  1. Attach stepper motor to motor mount. M3 screws should still be a little loose, letting the motor move along the slots.
  2. Mount should then be attached to frame. Position as centrally as possible.
  3. Add pulley to Motor and try to level with pulleys on lead screws. A straight edge like a ruler can be helpful here.
  4. Push M5 screw through relevant hole for idler pulley. Add the nylon spacer (or nut if using instead), then add washers (2 for each). Finally put on the pulley and add final nylock nut. These also need to be checked for height against the other pulleys. You may need to add or remove washers to get the heights right.
  5. If the X axis is straight now, you can attach the belt. This should be threaded around the pulleys as show in the pictures. The last pulley can be a little tight due to limitations in the frame, but should go over without too much trouble.
  6. Tension the belt by pulling the Motor back in it's slot then tightening the screws. Given how this works having really high tension is not as critical as it is on the other axes.
  7. Manually rotate the motor pulley (with care!) to ensure the mechanism moves freely, and doesn't bind up.

Firmware changes

You need to invert the Z motor direction in the firmware for this to work correctly. That is the only change you need to make (unless you have changed thread pitch at all).

Important Notes

It has been pointed out to me that unless alignment is perfect, having the screws supported on both end will lead to binding. I don't have a problem with this myself, however if you do, the best thing is to simply pop out the bottom bearings and not use them.

As with any modification to a printer, make sure you test well, through the whole range of motion of the Z axis to ensure it moves freely and does not bind.

You may need to up the current to the Z motor slightly, as it is working a little harder than it was.

I needed to buy a longer Motor wire due to moving the Z axis. Depending how you mount your electronics, you may not need to do this.

Feedback

I greatly appreciate any feedback you have! If you have an problems, I am happy to help where I can.

Improvements from v1

  • Removed some material to improve strength.
  • Added ribs to upper brackets to improve strength.
  • Fixed an alignment issue with some holes.
  • Adjusted hole spacing under bearing blocks so all previous holes present.
  • Increased travel for motor to allow more belt tension if required.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Recommend Concentric supports for Top brackets as easier to remove. Z Nut holder does not require supports.

Unlike thingirob brackets, I have allowed tollerance in these parts where required, so should be able to print at 100% scaling.

comments.text: Removing the bottom bearing with your current design will cause more issues. Where people (including my own printers) remove the bearing to negate any Z axis shaft wobble is when you have 2 Z motors and so the forces on the shaft are released but the shaft is supported by the motor and coupling... this is proven as a sound solution to the common problem of not stright leadscrews.
comments.author: NinjaCookie

comments.text: Yes removing the bearing can cause potential issues, but only under very high tension from my test. Why you would need to put this design through that I don't know. I'm currently reviewing it myself using pillow block bearings as mentioned previously. This would help with the alignment somewhat. I have looked at mksa's design and the parts for his I don't think would stand up to tension that well. I have followed the openbuilds actuators for some time and they basically all run one the same principle but with higher manufacturing tolerances. I'm still testing this, and have had mine working really nicely for a while now. I will be interested to see what you come up with regarding the bottom bearing.

title: Mostly Printed 3D Printer Optimized to Print ABS
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Newer version using belts: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2387735

Mostly Printed 3D Printer Optimized to Print ABS. The XY mechanism is of my own devising and as far as I can find it is brand new. It is a combination of ideas taken from the Ultimaker gantry and Richard Horne's Sli3dr Printer but I believe better and simpler than either.

3D Printer Features:
Features Genuine E3D V6 hotend and graphic controller at $350 price point.
Modular construction. Size can be adjusted by adding or removing modules.
More area inside printer is usable as print area compared to many other designs.
All motors outside of build area to allow heated chamber.
Integrated cable management for clean look.
Nearly all parts 3D printed, easily enclosed for printing ABS.
Innovative XY mechanism with excellent accuracy and low parts cost.
XY can use belts or filament and round or other linear rails (this version uses filament and round rails).
Can use bowden or direct extruder (this version uses bowden).
Avoidance of over-constrained x and y axis ease build tolerances.

Orientation of parts for printing is left to the user. Refer to parts list, included jpegs and pictures zip file for helpful assembly hints.

No assembly instructions currently so I suggest you not attempt this printer unless you are handy. Please let me know if you find errors. If you would like to see build instruction videos and hood/enclosure design, let me know.

title: Alexa and Sinclair-10's Musical Instrument Toys

description.text:
From the book LEO the Maker Prince:
http://www.leothemakerprince.com
http://www.amazon.com/LEO-Maker-Prince-Journeys-Printing/dp/1457183145 Alexa looked for toys to download for her and her brothers to play with. She decided to make different musical instruments so they could form a band together. There is a rubber band guitar, a percussive shaker, a "woodpecker" knocker and an ocarina.

For the ocarina, the file ocarina_side_split will give you the instrument as pictured in the book. Be sure to clean the hollows out of the main body and mouth piece well. Then glue the two halves together so that they are sealed. There is also a file for the ocarina with the split through the center (ocarina_split_face) if you prefer that look. If you have a printer that can print well without support, feel free to contact me for the file of the ocarina without splits. There are many resources online where you can learn how to play an ocarina, such as: http://www.ocarina.co.uk/how-to-play-ocarinas/

For the rubber band guitar (files rubberbandguitar and pegs_to_print):
  • Grow the pegs separate from the main body. Clean the support material off all parts.
  • Get 4 rubber bands and cut them so they are no longer a loop.
  • Tie a knot at one end of each rubber band and slip the knotted end into the keyhole on the taller edge of the main piece.
  • Slip the other end of each rubber band into the holes on the shorter platform.
  • Place the pegs in the holes. The round edge should face inward.
  • Rotate the pegs down so that they are flat with the platform and lock the rubber bands into place
  • To tune the guitar, lift each peg one at a time and pull the rubberband to get it tighter and then push the peg back down to set.

For the Shaker Instrument (shaker_pyramid), grow the piece as a hollow shell and pause the machine to fill it with rice or something similar before the top is reached. For the stripes shown in the book, each color is 30% and the black stripes are 5 % each. There is also a fun egg shape that you can make using the shaker_egg file. It will wobble slightly when put on a surface and nudged. For the pattern, our total layer count was 414
  • Load purple, Pause at 124
  • Load black, Pause at 145
  • Load Blue, Pause at 269
  • Load black, Pause at 291
    FILL WITH RICE
  • Load Orange
    End at 414

comments.text: Could you describe the woodpecker instrument a little bit?
comments.author: cscottnet

comments.text: Sure! The Woodpecker is a percussive "noisemaker". It's essentially like a plastic bell that has a sliding cylinder pierced through it. At the end of the cylinder are two solid balls so when you wave it in a back and forth "ringing" motion it knocks repeatedly on the outer sides of the bell shape.
comments.author: cscottnet

comments.author: jubr

comments.text: How exciting that you have a brand new ocarina! Were you able to print it whole without support?  If there is support, make sure it's all cleared out. Otherwise, the key to having the ocarina work is to have the slanted portion under the mouthpiece be free of obstructions. Let me know if any of those help.
comments.author: jubr

I have been thinking that I should make a different thingiverse page for every one of the instruments as it's a bit confusing and overwhelming. Feel free to offer feedback on how your print goes and what would make your experience better.

author: s3rkan

description.text:
Customizable mount for an NTC C.H.I.P single board computer that I can use with my monitor attached to a stand; that is why the CHIP is not mounted in the center of the VESA mount. I originally drew a dual mount for the C.H.I.P., but I wanted to make a customizable version. I am starting with a single CHIP mount, as I expect that to be the most common.

If you want to change the orientation of the board, just swap chip width and length, and then you can turn on or off the top / bottom or left / right sides as you wish.

Planned additions:

  • DONE: Adding the screw hole for the CHIP to better secure the board. Currently it is relying on tight tolerances to hold the board in by friction.
  • DONE: Add in the dual CHIP support even though I no longer plan on using it this way. (Mainly for OpenSCAD learning.)
  • Done: Have a separate wall thickness from plate thickness.
